body:
Comment 4 by **gorgonzola@online.de**: 
am not shure why you are so aggressive. however, you said nothing to the point. and,
to your points i already answered in my first entry. yes, ed is POSIX (not *nix), as
is lots of stuff that never met my HD. The point i am making is:

"there are about 300 packages installed on my linux system and *none* needs "ed"."

saying nothing more than *ed is commonly available* is not a point at all. there's
lots available. do you still use xfig? how many tcl/tk progs do you run? distros even
ship dialects of basic. which shell do you expect? did you install moonlight to watch
the president? at least it has a wider user base. there are lots of small tools
nobody really uses seriously. many are deprecated.

sed is not obsolete because it is widely in use! otherwise, it were. however, i wrote
that ed is *redundant*. this is the point. it is as same redundant as hundreds of
further packages on your favourite distro: because really nobody except
traditionalists like you seem to be using that stuff.

for example, simpleinit is deprecated and will be dropped from util-linux because
"nobody uses it!" that is the reason, and not that there is ng-init or whatever more
complicated available. this is why people stick with gdm or kdm and mainly ignore
xdm. ed is just a redundant draw-in from your side. as said, i installed it only to
be able to install go. and this after more than 10 years of an ed-less time. think
about it!

stop! there was another moment i installed it for short because, wtf, the first adobe
reader for linux used it to let the user agree to the license !?
